body.p: In Helion OpenStack 2.0 Beta 2 we offer the Entry Scale Cloud model with two variations depending on the hypervisor you wish to use -- KVM or ESX.
The following list summarizes this configuration and it's purpose.
body.section:
Entry Scale Cloud
At minimum scale this model can be used to deploy a 3-4 node environment but can also scale up to include up to 100 compute nodes. This is illustrated by the list below:
Control Plane 3 nodes, hosts all management and ancillary services in a highly available cluster
Object Store All Swift services are contained in the control plane
Compute Nodes Min 1; Max 100
Block Storage (optional) 3 nodes (recommended to ensure high availability) for our backend options
Physical Network 1 pair of bonded NICs
Network Separation
EXTERNAL_API, EXTERNAL_VM, GUEST (vxlan), MGMT on separate VLANs
You can learn more about the hardware requirements here: Minimum Hardware Requirements
The network configuration supports separation of networks for:
Management - This network will be used for all internal traffic between the cloud services. It is an untagged network.
External API - This is the network that users will use to make requests to the cloud. It is a tagged network.
External VM - This network will be used to provide access to VMs (via floating IP addresses). It is a tagged network.
Guest - This network will carry traffic between VMs on private networks within the cloud. It is a tagged network.
The requirement to have a dedicated network for OS-install and system deployment has been removed. To re-use the deployment network as part of the operational network the following conditions must be adhered to:
The network IP addresses used for the operating system install (i.e. baremetalConfig.yml and servers.yml) must belong to a Network that is used for your cloud infrastructure (e.g. in networks.yml).
The network that re-uses those addresses must be un-tagged. In the example entry-scale model the management network is:
Mgmt 10.2.1.0/24 VLAN: 100 (untagged)
In the baremetalConfig.yml file, servers are listed as:
baremetal_servers: - node_name: controller1 node_type: CCN-001-001 pxe_mac_addr: b2:72:8d:ac:7c:6f pxe_interface: eth2 pxe_ip_addr: 192.168.10.3 ilo_ip: 192.168.9.3
In the servers.yml file, servers will show as:
- id: controller1 role: ROLE-CCN ip-addr: 192.168.10.3
The values in the baremetalConfig.yml and servers.yml definition files need to members of the CIDR used for the untagged network (in this case the MGMT network).
This cloud model also supports the physical bonding of network interfaces (NIC bonding), see Interface Models for more details on that feature.
